CatDescriptText: Paul Hopkins, janitor, Beltzhoover and Norma Davenport, stenographer, Monongahela, were part of the Pittsburgher's Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 18, 1960 with question: "Do you think that economic status, race, or religion influences court decisions in civil and criminal cases?" Paul Hopkins' answer reads: "I don't follow jury cases too closely but I would say that I don't think that these things enter in the rulings but juries stick to the facts instead."  Norma Davenport's answer reads: "I do believe that juries can be influenced and I think that a minority of them are influenced into rendering bad verdicts."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Paul Hopkins wearing light colored dot patterned shirt, and hat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade and May Building, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Norma Davenport wearing light colored sleeveless dress, carrying basket style handbag, standing on Liberty Avenue across from Jenkins Arcade, Downtown
